bibl.title: Letter from John J. Moran to Philip Showalter Hench, October 15, 1940

div1.p: Moran informs Hench that he should be able to acquire the shack on the Rojas farm, which he is sure is the infected-clothing building, for no charge.

div1.head: Letter from John J. Moran to Philip Showalter Hench, October 15, 1940
div1.opener:
Havana, Oct. 15, 1940.
Dr. Philip S. Hench,
MAYO CLINIC,
Rochester, Minn.
Dear Dr. Hench:
div1.p:
As per your letter of the 12th, Pogolotti and I went to
see Sr. Adrian Macía, pronounced “Mah-see-ah”, this morning, one of the
most influential of the three parties who own the unbuilt upon grounds
of the “Finca San Jose”, including the limestone quarry and, per se, the
little shack in which we are all so deeply interested now. I have his
assurance that the shack is yours for the purpose you have in view and
that sufficient ground around where the shack stands is also yours, if
you should decide to leave it there, conditional upon consent of the two
widows who, jointly with him, own the other two thirds of the ground,
including the brick factory, the old and new quarries, etc., etc., Zun-
zunegui having the limekilns leased from the parties mentioned but having
no interest in the property itself. It appears that Z. sub-leases to the
old lady who occupies the shack but is not the owner of either shack or
any part of the ground around it. Sr. Macía has the greatest confidence
that the two widows referred to will give their consent, after he explains
your laudable purpose to them. The shack and a sufficient parcel to
surround it, so far as Sr. Macía is concerned, would be ceded GRATIS. It
is barely possible that provision to replace the shack by a modest wooden
one might be in order and I do not think a shack of that kind would cost
so very much. In the first place, it need not be double-walled. On the
other hand, replacement may not be at all necessary, so he informs me, in
view of the fact that whatever the old lady pays there to Z. is not in-
cluded in his lease on the quarry. I gather that Z. and the old lady are,
to a certain extent, squatters, the house having belonged to the grounds
ever since the Americans left it to Dr. Rojas. In the meantime, while we
were in Sr. Macias' office, he telephoned to Z. to please see to it that
the shack was not to be touched or altered in any way until further notice
from him (Macía). Since the airmail is due to close within a half hour,
I cannot write you very much more than this.

Please write a letter to Sr. Macía, via AIRMAIL, upon
receipt of this, thanking him for his generous and noble impulse in
connection with this matter, as expressed in the above lines, through
Sr. Pogolotti and your humble servant. His address is as follows:
Sr. Adrian Macía,
Manzana de Gomez No. 325,
HABANA, CUBA.

Too little time to explain why you have not received the
photostats. I hope to get them off tomorrow by airmail. I DO NOT LEAVE
HAVANA UNTIL SUNDAY NIGHT, OCTOBER 20TH. Do not know how you arrived
at date of my departure as the 16th.
